The son of Master Zhao learned his father’s zither, yet likewise ended his life without achievement. If Huizi did not engage in disputation and Master Zhao did not play the zither, what completion or diminution could there have been? The reason their Way was diminished lay precisely in their small achievements. If this can be called completion, then even I, too, am complete. If this cannot be called completion, then neither things nor I have achieved anything.

Thus, the radiance of perplexing doubt is what the sage contemplates—this "radiance" refers to concealing one’s brilliance and blending with the dust, echoing Laozi’s "dim and murky," meaning to harmonize with the world without flaunting one’s views. To shine without dazzling is what the sage seeks. It is not that he does not employ his wisdom, but rather lodges it in the commonplace. This is what is meant by "illuminating with clarity."

This passage concludes a far-reaching intent. From the opening "speech is not mere breath" downward, through "where is the Dao hidden that there is truth and falsehood?"—where the Dao is obscured by small achievements and words are concealed by splendor—even to the point of affirming what one denies and denying what one affirms, the argument rises in layers. The first culminates in "nothing is better than clarity." The second, from the pivot of the Dao attaining the center of the ring, again concludes with "nothing is better than clarity." Next, the analogy of the horse is introduced to illustrate that the Dao is universally interconnected, leading to the assertion that only the enlightened know this unity. Then, by not employing one’s views but lodging them in the ordinary, the character of the Dao is subtly revealed. The passage then borrows the example of the monkey-keeper, whose name and reality were not diminished, to expound upon the theme of diminution. The diminution of the Dao arises from the completion of attachment. This phrase, "the completion of attachment," reaches back to the earlier assertion that "once one receives one’s completed form" and "follows one’s completed mind as a teacher." The two meanings of "completion" imply: if one receives one’s form, this is the completion of attachment, and thus the Dao is diminished—here there is both completion and diminution. But if one follows one’s completed mind as a teacher, then there is fundamentally no completion or diminution. It is because of the completion of form that the distinctions of right and wrong become manifest—this is the root of it. Thus, the two ideas of "completed form" and "completed mind" form the backbone of the argument. The obscuring of the Dao by small achievements and the concealment of words by splendor have long existed, all stemming from a failure to awaken to the great Dao. Therefore, it was first declared: "nothing is better than clarity." Then, discussing the pivot of the Dao, it was again said: "thus, nothing is better than clarity." Now, having argued to the end, the conclusion returns to completion and diminution, pointing out that Huizi was the foremost among the unenlightened, clinging to the disputation of "hard and white" and obscuring his entire life. Thus, in the end, it highlights the sage who embodies the "radiance of perplexing doubt"—one who does not insist on being right—and returns to the enlightened one who does not employ his views but lodges them in the ordinary. This concludes with: "this is what is meant by 'nothing is better than clarity.'" The text, beginning from "speech is not mere breath," spans over seven hundred characters before reaching this grand conclusion. Its words and meaning are like a snake in the grass—only its undulations and meanderings are visible, while its form remains elusive. Without a true eye, it cannot be easily discerned.

As for the completion and diminution of the three masters: Master Zhao’s pertains to the completion and diminution of his craft; Master Kuang’s, to the completion and diminution of his form; and Huizi’s, to the completion and diminution of the Dao. The overarching conclusion is that the Dao is obscured by small achievements and words are concealed by splendor, ultimately returning to the sage. This sage is the one previously described as "only the enlightened know the universal interconnectedness" and "not employing one’s views but lodging them in the ordinary." Gazing deeply, one perceives the boundless waves and vital currents of this old master’s prose, where its intricacies defy grasp. The phrase "this is what is meant by 'nothing is better than clarity'" concludes the chapter beginning with "speech is not mere breath." From here, the discussion shifts to the sage who embodies "perplexing doubt," launching into the theme of the sage’s absence of right and wrong, leading to the following passage: "without preference, following what is so"—over two hundred and thirty characters forming another chapter.

Now, suppose there is someone who speaks thus—do his words resemble this kind? By "this," I refer to the sage of "perplexing doubt," who is without right or wrong. Does this speaker’s discourse resemble such a sage? Or does it not? Whether it resembles or does not resemble, if one joins with it as a kind, then it differs in no way from that sage. Here, "that" refers to the sage mentioned above. This passage concludes the discussion of the two sages, urging self-realization and the forgetting of one’s own rightness.

Though this is so, let me attempt to speak of it. Though there is fundamentally no right or wrong, this has not yet been thoroughly penetrated. Therefore, let me try to discuss it.
chunks.overlap_context: ly to Huizi, who had not truly understood the Dao yet forcibly claimed to understand it, and further sought to illuminate it for others—thus he achieved no great success and ended his life in the obscurity of "hard and white"). And his son ended with the threads of Zhao’s zither (the above spoke of Huizi’s completion and diminution; this speaks of Master Zhao’s completion and diminution)—his life achieved nothing (Huizi ended in the obscurity of "hard and white," thus his life achieved nothing).

chunks.original_text: 有始也者（即老子“无名，天地之始”），有未始有始也者（此言有始亦无，谓无始也。 即老子云“同谓之玄”），有未始有“夫未始有始也者”（此未始有亦无，即老子云“玄之又玄、众妙之门”。 此乃单言无形大道之原也）。 有有也者（有，即天地人物，老子“有名，万物之母”也），有无也者（因天地之有，乃推“无名，天地之始”。 此盖就有形，以推道本无形也），有未始有无也者（此言天地万物有形，出于无形。 而大道体中，有无不立，故云未始有），有未始有“夫未始有无也者”（上言有无俱无，此言俱无亦无，迥绝称谓，方是大道之玄同之域，故以此称为虚无妙道）。 俄而有无矣（言大道体中，了无名相，一法不立，故强称虚无大道。 忽然生起有无，而不知谁使之也。 前云若有真宰，而不知有所为使，直论到此，方回头照顾，暗点于此），而未知有无之果孰有孰无也（言大道体中，有无不立，即今之有无，谁使之为有无耶？ 所谓若有真宰，而求不得其朕。 今果返观至此，有无尚无，安有是非之辩哉）。 今我则已有谓矣（言有无既无，了绝名相，何有言论之辩耶？ 然我既已于无言之中，而有言说矣，但我言本无言），而未知吾所谓之其果有谓乎？ 其果无谓乎（言我今既已有言，但言其无言耳。 如前所谓鷇音是也，原出于天机，了无是非之相。 世人但观我无言之言，其果有言说乎？ 果无言说乎？ 但悟此无言之言，则是非自泯矣）？ 已前释言非吹也，盖有机心之言也。 今庄子既说到忘言玄同之处，意谓我今虽已有言，乃从真宰而发，是无言之言。 若会我无言之言，则忘言而归一致矣。 下文重释忘言归一，大小玄同，了无是非。 如此，乃真是也。 夫天下莫大于秋豪之末，而泰山为小； 莫寿于殇子（襁褓中子），而彭祖为夭（此二句极难理会。 以上文已论归大道之原，今将以大道而一是非。 意谓若以有形而观有形，则大小、寿夭一定而不可易者。 今若以大道而观有形，则秋毫虽小，而体合太虚； 而太山有形，只太虚中拳石耳。 故秋毫莫大，而太山为小也。 殇子虽夭，而与无始同原； 而彭祖乃无始中一物耳。 故莫寿于殇子，而彭祖为夭也。 若如此以道而观，则小者不小，而大者不大； 夭者不夭，而寿者非寿矣。 如此则天地同根，万物一体，何是非之有哉）。 天地与我并生，而万物与我为一（以道观之，万物一体，则天地与我并生，万物与我为一）。 既已为一矣，且得有言乎（既以为一，物我两忘，更复何言）？ 既已谓之一矣，且得无言乎（既已称谓为一，则言恶乎存而不可哉）？ 一与言为二（谓无形之一，今称谓之为一，则是两一成二矣），二与一为三（今又以言说彼两一，则观待而为三矣）。 自此以往，巧历不能得，而况其凡乎（自以言相待而为三，则相待无穷。 纵有巧于历数者，不得终穷矣。 况其凡乎）！ 故自无适有，以至于三，而况自有适有乎（言自无才适有，则已成三； 而况自有适有，则无极矣）！ 无适焉，因是已（无适者，谓安心于未始有已前，则湛然常一而不迁矣。 前云，众人因是，而有是非； 圣人不由，而照之于天，亦因是也。 故一往论到未始有物已前，天地万物混而为一，故不离于道，如此为真是。
chunks.translated_text:
There is that which has a beginning (this refers to Laozi’s "The nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth"), there is that which has not yet had a beginning (here, even "having a beginning" is absent—meaning "without beginning." This corresponds to Laozi’s "These two emerge together but differ in name"), and there is that which has not yet had "that which has not yet had a beginning" (here, even "not yet having" is absent, corresponding to Laozi’s "Mystery upon mystery—the gateway of all subtleties." This speaks solely of the origin of the formless Dao).

There is that which is "having" (this "having" refers to heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things, as in Laozi’s "The named is the mother of the ten thousand things"), there is that which is "non-having" (from the existence of heaven and earth, one infers "The nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth." This is to trace from the formed back to the formless origin of the Dao), there is that which has not yet had "non-having" (this means that the formed heaven, earth, and ten thousand things arise from the formless, yet within the essence of the Dao, neither "having" nor "non-having" is established, hence it is said "not yet had"), and there is that which has not yet had "that which has not yet had non-having" (the above speaks of both "having" and "non-having" as absent; here, even "both absent" is absent, utterly beyond all designation. Only then does one reach the realm of the Dao’s profound sameness, thus naming it the wondrous Dao of emptiness and non-being).

Suddenly, there is "having" and "non-having" (within the essence of the Dao, there are no names or forms, not a single dharma established—hence it is forcibly called the vast and empty Dao. Yet suddenly, "having" and "non-having" arise, and none know what causes this. Earlier, it was said, "as if there were a true master," yet one cannot discern its traces. Now, turning back to reflect, it subtly points to this), yet it remains unknown whether "having" and "non-having" are truly "having" or "non-having" (within the essence of the Dao, neither "having" nor "non-having" is established. Even now, who causes them to be "having" or "non-having"? This is what was meant by "as if there were a true master," yet its traces cannot be found. Now, upon returning to observe this, even "having" and "non-having" are absent—how then could there be any debate over right and wrong?).

Now, I have already spoken (if "having" and "non-having" are both absent, all names and forms are extinguished—how could there be any debate through words? Yet I have already spoken within the realm of wordlessness, though my words are fundamentally without words), yet it remains unknown whether what I have called "speaking" is truly speaking or truly not speaking (I have now already spoken, but my words are merely words of wordlessness, as in the earlier example of the fledgling’s cry, which arises from the celestial mechanism without any trace of right or wrong. People see only my wordless words—are they truly words? Or truly not words? If one awakens to these wordless words, then right and wrong naturally vanish).

The preceding explanation of words was not like the wind’s blowing—it was speech arising from a calculating mind. Now, Zhuangzi has spoken of the state of forgetting words and attaining profound sameness, meaning that though I have now spoken, my words arise from the true master and are words of wordlessness. If one comprehends my wordless words, then one forgets words and returns to unity.

The following passage further explains forgetting words and returning to unity, where great and small are the same, and right and wrong are utterly absent. Only thus is it truly so.

In the world, nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small; nothing lives longer than an infant who dies young, yet Pengzu is short-lived (these two lines are exceedingly difficult to grasp. Having already discussed returning to the origin of the Dao, Zhuangzi now unifies right and wrong through the Dao. If one observes the formed through the formed, then great and small, long life and early death are fixed and unchangeable. But if one observes the formed through the Dao, then an autumn hair, though small, embodies the vastness of the void, while Mount Tai, though formed, is but a pebble within it. Thus, nothing is greater than an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small. An infant who dies young, though short-lived, shares the same origin as the beginningless, while Pengzu is but a single thing within it. Thus, nothing lives longer than an infant who dies young, yet Pengzu is short-lived. If one observes thus through the Dao, then the small is not small, and the great is not great; the short-lived is not short-lived, and the long-lived is not long-lived. In this way, heaven and earth share the same root, and the ten thousand things are one body—how could there be right and wrong?).

Heaven and earth are born together with me, and the ten thousand things and I are one (observing through the Dao, the ten thousand things are one body, thus heaven and earth are born together with me, and the ten thousand things and I are one). Since we are already one, can there be speech? (Having become one, self and things are both forgotten—what more is there to say?) Since we have already called it "one," can there be no speech? (Having already named it "one," how could words not arise?) The one and words make two (the formless "one" is now named "one," thus two "ones" become two), and two and one make three (now, with words describing these two "ones," they become three through mutual dependence). From this point onward, even the most skilled mathematician cannot reckon it—how much less the ordinary person! (From the mutual dependence of words to become three, dependence continues endlessly. Even one skilled in calculation cannot exhaust it—how much less the ordinary person!)

Thus, from non-being to being, one reaches three—how much more from being to being! (From non-being just reaching being, one has already become three—how much more from being to being, which is boundless!) Do not proceed thus, but rest here (not proceeding means settling the mind before "not yet having" began, where it remains serene, constant, and unchanging. Earlier, it was said that the multitude follow "this" and thus have right and wrong, while the sage does not follow but illuminates it through heaven—this is also "resting here." Thus, carrying the discussion to before "not yet having things," heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things merge into one, never departing from the Dao. Only this is truly so).

chunks.original_text: 所言圣人因是者，乃无适为是，此正照之于天也。 此文之照应处）！ 此一节，明妙契玄同、天地同根、万物一体； 安心于大道，不起分别，则了无是非。 此乃真是。 故结之曰“无适焉，因是已”。 下文又重提起一是字，乃是非之根原。 夫道未始有封（本无形相、人我界限），言未始有常（常者，执定不化之意，乃是非之言也。 任道而言，则无可、不可，了无一定是非之相），为是而有畛也（只因执了一个是字，故有是非分别之辩）。 请言其畛：有左、有右，有伦、有义，有分、有辩，有竞、有争，此之谓八德（意谓从无适有，则有无二字，已成对待矣。 既有之后，则有左右之序； 有左右，则有伦义； 有伦义，则有分辩； 则有争竞。 此相因而有，乃执定而不可化者。 盖从一是字为病根，只如以左为是，而右则决不可易。 世俗之情，以此分辩为能，故谓之八德。 此德，乃能义）。 前一往从迷至悟，说到大道根底，因是已一句，已结绝了。 至此又提起，大道本无是非，不知这些分辩执着，从何而有。 只要提出一个是字为病根，要使人识得破。 六合之外，圣人存而不论（道包天地，与太虚同体，本无封畛。 只为众人迷大道，而执己见为是，故是非之辩，由之而起。 圣人心与道合，即六合之外，未尝不知； 但存之而不论。 以非耳目之所及，恐生是非，故不论耳）； 六合之内，圣人论而不议（六合之内，圣人未尝不周知万物，但只论其大纲，如天经地义，以立君臣、父子之序，而不议其所以之详）。 春秋经世，先王之志，圣人议而不辩（春秋乃为经世君臣、父子之大经、大法，圣人但议其名分、品节之详，而不辩其是非之曲折）。 故分也者，有不分也（夫道一而已，本来不分。 但在天地有形之内，而人伦之序，不得不分。 人物虽分，而道未尝分，所谓性一而已矣）； 辩也者，有不辩也（虽天地间有众口之辩，其实有不可辩者，乃忘言之大道存焉）。 曰何也（谓何以有不辩、不分之义耶）？ 圣人怀之（圣人与道为一，明知万化之多，而未尝分； 明知众口之辩，而道非言之可及。 故葆光敛耀，怀之于心，而不示于人），众人辩之以相示也（众人其实未达大道之原，而强不知以为知，且执以己见为必是，而以哓哓之辩，夸示于人，故大道隐矣）。 故曰辩也者，有不见也（故曰者，引古语也。 老子云：善者不辩，辩者不善）。 此一节，释滑疑之圣人，与道为一，以至无适焉、因是已。 意谓圣人心同太虚，即六合内外之事，未尝不知，但怀之而不辩，以显好辩者，其实未明大道也。 下文重释不言不辩之义。 夫大道不称（道本无名，故不可以称），大辩不言（不言之辩，是非了然），大仁不仁（不是有心要仁），大廉不嗛（嗛，满也。 不以廉自满），大勇不忮（忮，害也。 大勇，乃自全道力，非害于人也）。 道昭而不道（谓大道昭昭，言则非道），言辩而不及（道本绝言，纵有言辩，亦不能及），仁常而不成（仁若常持有心，则有私爱，故不能大成万物），廉清而不信（信，实也。 谓矫矫以自清立名，则无实德矣），勇忮而不成（勇若有害人之意，则为血气，而不成道义之勇矣）。 五者圆而几向方矣（五者名虽可行于世，以皆出有心，卒莫能行，故几向方矣）！

The sage who "follows this" does so by taking non-proceeding as "this"—this is precisely illuminating it through heaven. (Here lies the textual correspondence!)

This passage elucidates the wondrous union with the mysterious, the shared root of heaven and earth, and the oneness of the ten thousand things. Settling the mind in the great Dao, without arising distinctions, one is utterly free from right and wrong—this alone is true. Thus it concludes: "Do not proceed thus, but rest here."

Below, the text again raises the word "this," the root of right and wrong. The Dao has never had boundaries (it originally lacks form or distinctions between self and others), nor has it ever had constancy (constancy here means rigid fixation, the source of right-and-wrong assertions. Following the Dao in speech, there is no "can" or "cannot," no fixed right or wrong). Yet by taking "this" as real, boundaries arise (merely grasping a single "this" gives rise to the distinctions of right and wrong).

Let us speak of these boundaries: there is left and right, there are relationships and righteousness, there are divisions and debates, there are competitions and conflicts—these are called the eight virtues (meaning that from non-being to being, the duality of being and non-being already forms opposition. Once being exists, there arises the order of left and right; with left and right, there are relationships and righteousness; with relationships and righteousness, there are divisions and debates; and from these, competitions and conflicts emerge. These arise in succession, fixed and unchanging. The root of the illness lies in the single word "this"—for example, taking left as right makes right utterly unchangeable. Worldly sentiments regard such distinctions as skill, hence calling them the eight virtues. Here, "virtue" means capability).

Earlier, the discussion moved from delusion to awakening, reaching the root of the great Dao, and the phrase "rest here" concluded it. Here, it raises the point again: the great Dao originally has no right or wrong—how do these distinctions and attachments arise? It merely points to the word "this" as the root of the illness, urging people to see through it.

Beyond the six directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss (the Dao encompasses heaven and earth, sharing the same body as the great void, originally without boundaries. Only because the multitude are deluded by the great Dao and cling to their own views as right do the debates of right and wrong arise. The sage’s mind merges with the Dao, so even beyond the six directions, they are not unaware; yet they preserve it without discussion, for it lies beyond the reach of ears and eyes, lest right and wrong arise). Within the six directions, the sage discusses but does not debate (within the six directions, the sage does not fail to comprehend all things, but only discusses their great principles—such as the heavenly constants and earthly duties—to establish the order of ruler and minister, father and child, without debating their details).

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* governs the world, embodying the intent of the former kings; the sage debates but does not argue (the *Spring and Autumn* serves as the great canon and law for governing the world’s rulers, ministers, fathers, and children. The sage merely debates the details of names and ranks without arguing the intricacies of right and wrong).

Thus, where there is division, there is also non-division (the Dao is one alone, originally undivided. Yet within the formed world of heaven and earth, the order of human relationships cannot but be divided. Though people and things are divided, the Dao is never divided—what is called "nature is one alone"). Where there is debate, there is also non-debate (though the world has countless debates, there are things that cannot be debated, for the great Dao of wordless understanding resides therein).

Why is this so? The sage embraces it (the sage is one with the Dao, clearly knowing the multiplicity of transformations yet never dividing them; clearly knowing the debates of many mouths, yet the Dao cannot be reached by words. Thus, they conceal their brilliance and hold it in their hearts without displaying it to others). The multitude debate it to display to one another (the multitude, in truth, have not grasped the origin of the great Dao, yet they feign knowledge, clinging to their own views as necessarily right, and with clamorous debates, boast to others—thus the great Dao is obscured).

Thus it is said: those who debate do not see (this quotes an ancient saying. Laozi said: "The good do not debate; those who debate are not good").

This passage explains that the sage who dissolves doubts is one with the Dao, reaching "do not proceed thus, but rest here." It means the sage’s mind is like the great void: though they do not fail to know the affairs within and beyond the six directions, they embrace it without debate, revealing that those who love debate have not truly understood the great Dao. Below, the text further explains the meaning of non-speech and non-debate.

The great Dao cannot be named (the Dao originally has no name, so it cannot be designated). Great debate does not speak (the debate of non-speech makes right and wrong clear). Great benevolence is not benevolent (it is not a matter of deliberately being benevolent). Great integrity is not boastful (boastful means full. It does not take integrity as a source of pride). Great courage does not harm (harm means injury. Great courage arises from preserving the power of the Dao, not from injuring others).

When the Dao is made manifest, it is no longer the Dao (when the great Dao is made evident, speech departs from it). When words debate, they do not reach it (the Dao is originally beyond words; even with verbal debates, they cannot attain it). Benevolence, when constant, does not succeed (if benevolence is constantly held with intent, it becomes partial love, thus failing to fully accomplish the ten thousand things). Integrity, when pure, is not trustworthy (trustworthy means real. To stand out with purity for the sake of reputation is to lack true virtue). Courage, when harmful, does not succeed (if courage harbors intent to harm others, it is mere blood and qi, not the courage of Dao and righteousness).

These five, though rounded, nearly verge on the square (though these five names may be practiced in the world, as they all arise from intent, they ultimately cannot be realized—thus they nearly verge on the square).

Who knows the eloquence of silence, the Dao that cannot be spoken? If one can know this, it is called the Heavenly Treasury (to say that the realm of the unknown is the origin of the great Dao—here, there is fundamentally no debate or discourse. Pour into it, yet it is never full (the body of the great Dao is empty; even the vast sea cannot compare to its capacity. Thus, the waters of heaven and earth arise within it, yet it is never filled); draw from it, yet it never runs dry (even if heaven and earth draw from it, it is never exhausted). Yet one does not know whence it comes (this is what is meant by "empty yet inexhaustible, active yet ever-flowing, yet one does not know its source")—this is called "preserving the light" (to preserve is to conceal without revealing. Earlier, it spoke of "the radiance of doubt and confusion, which the sage takes as his model"—here, it concludes by pointing to its meaning, saying this is called "preserving the light").

Earlier, it spoke of "the radiance of doubt and confusion, which the sage takes as his model," and thus presented matters within the six directions, both inner and outer. The sage knows all things but does not speak of them, for the great Dao is originally without knowledge or debate. The sage abides in the vast emptiness, roaming through the human world, harmonizing his light with the dust, shining yet not dazzling—this is called "preserving the light." The sage’s work must reach this point to be complete, and thus it is said to be what the sage takes as his model.

Therefore, long ago, Yao asked Shun: "I wish to attack the states of Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao. Yet when I face south, I feel unsettled. What is the reason?" (This "unsettled" means that in his heart, he was determined to attack them, yet afterward, he could not let it go, not knowing why.) Shun replied: "Those three rulers dwell among the mugwort and reeds. Why should you feel unsettled? (This means Yao’s heart was not broad enough to embrace all things. Moreover, the three rulers occupied such humble positions, like mugwort and reeds, that they should not have troubled his heart. If you feel unsettled, why not expand yourself?) Long ago, when ten suns appeared together, all things were illuminated—how much more so for one whose virtue surpasses the sun? (This means Yao’s virtue had not yet reached its fullness. When ten suns appeared together, their light was vast and bright, illuminating all things—how much more so for one whose virtue surpasses the sun? If one’s virtue were already perfected, it would be vast and luminous, embracing all things—how could the insignificance of those three rulers trouble him?)"

This illustrates that the sage who preserves the light has a heart as vast as the Heavenly Treasury—what the sage takes as his model is achieved only when his work reaches this point. If one’s work has not yet reached this level, the heart is not broad and cannot embrace all things. Thus, even the great sage Yao had his shortcomings. The image of ten suns appearing together serves as a metaphor for advancing virtue, summarizing the preceding meaning and concluding the intent from "words are not like the wind" onward.

The following passage reaffirms that the perfected one halts at what he does not know, revealing the sage’s accomplishment, and concludes with "death and life do not alter him—how much less the beginnings of profit and harm?"

Nie Que asked Wang Ni: "Do you know what all things agree upon as right?" He replied: "How would I know?" "Do you know what you do not know?" He replied: "How would I know?" How do I know that what I call knowing (this knowing is the knowledge of ordinary people) is not not-knowing? How do I know that what I call not-knowing (my not-knowing) is not knowing? Moreover, I once questioned you to illustrate that this is not true knowledge: When people sleep in damp places, they develop lumbar ailments and partial paralysis—yet does the loach fare so? When they dwell in trees, they tremble with fear—yet does the gibbon fare so? Among these three, which knows the proper dwelling? People eat the flesh of livestock, deer graze on grass, centipedes relish snakes, and owls feast on mice—among these four, which knows the true flavor? Gibbons mate with gibbons, deer couple with elk, and loaches swim with fish to conceive. Mao Qiang and Lady Li were beauties admired by all—yet fish seeing them plunged deep, birds seeing them soared high, and deer seeing them bolted away. Among these four, which knows the true beauty of the world?

From my perspective, the origins of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are tangled and confused—how could I discern their distinctions? Nie Que said: "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the perfected person likewise not know benefit and harm?" Wang Ni replied: "The perfected person is divine! Though great marshes burn, they cannot be scorched; though rivers and lakes freeze, they cannot be chilled; though thunder splits mountains and gales shake the seas, they cannot be startled. One who is thus rides the clouds and qi, mounts the sun and moon, and roams beyond the four seas. Death and life bring no change to them—how much less the beginnings of benefit and harm?"

This passage elaborates on the earlier statement that "the perfected person abides in what they do not know," showing how ordinary people mistake their partial knowledge for truth. With such judgments of right and wrong, how could I discern their distinctions? It concludes that the perfected person’s utmost unknowing transcends life and death—how could common understanding fathom this?

Below, it speaks of equalizing life and death, observing the world through the lens of dreams and waking to show that all under heaven are unawakened, and those who debate right and wrong are but dreaming within a dream. The prose is extraordinary, yet its meaning is perfectly sound.

Ququezi asked Changwuzi: "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in worldly affairs, does not pursue profit, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, and does not follow the Dao with intention. chunks.translated_text:
Thus, those who cling to the view of self and engage in contentious debates over right and wrong do so due to the error of delusion. Therefore, what follows points directly to the true master, urging one first to awaken to one’s original reality; to awaken to this original reality, one must first cast aside the bodily form. Hence the mention of the "hundred bones and nine orifices," guiding one to see through the bodily form and recognize the true master. If one awakens to the true master, then naturally every word spoken aligns with the Dao, all arising from the celestial truth—this is what is called the heavenly wind. The inconsistencies in today’s debates stem from the words of the calculating mind, thus clinging to right and wrong. Therefore, the opening of the discourse on right and wrong begins with the phrase, *"Now, words are not the blowing [of wind]"*—raising this to generate the many subsequent descriptions of right and wrong, all unfolding from the two characters "not blowing." Yet while ordinary people remain deluded and unawakened, the sage, having already awakened, is not swayed by the right and wrong of the multitude. Thus, whatever is spoken is reflected in heaven and earth. From this phrase, *"reflected in heaven,"* the public case for awakening is established. Hence, what follows argues that right and wrong need not be forcibly unified; one need only rest in the celestial balance, and without effort, all will naturally align. Through layer upon layer of discussion, it reaches the conclusion that in the end, no one can truly settle right and wrong. Like all the world, past and present, it is but a dream within a dream—only the great awakened sage can set it right. Even if one cannot await the great awakened sage, one need only realize the true master within each person, and the judgments of things and distinctions of right and wrong will become clear. Upon this awakening, right and wrong clarify themselves. Then, whatever is spoken arises from the celestial truth, no different from the earthly wind. Thus, the conclusion is drawn with the phrase *"responding with transforming sounds."*

If one has not yet fully awakened, then whatever is spoken should be reflected in heaven, and the work lies in resting in the celestial balance. Hence, the closing words: *"harmonizing with the celestial boundary."* This is the vital pulse and fundamental intent of the entire discourse. Yet the waves of the text surge boundlessly, making its depths difficult to fathom. If one can grasp its central meaning, then from beginning to end, it is coherent, rigorously structured, and not a single word is superfluous. This is what is meant by the *"divine transformations of literature, like spirits and ghosts."*

The following section concludes with form, shadow, and dream as metaphors to reveal the true work of cultivation. The shadow’s shadow (the shadow beyond the shadow) asks the shadow: *"Before, you were walking, now you are still; before, you were sitting, now you are rising. Why do you lack constancy?"* (meaning, why is there no fixed principle in your movements of walking, stopping, sitting, and rising). The shadow replies: *"Is it because I depend on something to be this way? Does what I depend on also depend on something else to be this way? Do I depend on the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada?"* (meaning, what I depend on is form, like the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada—mere things. What do they know?) *"How could I know why it is so? How could I know why it is not so?"* (meaning, that borrowed form is like an insensate clod, no different from a snake’s scales or a cicada’s wings, having nothing to do with the true master—it simply follows the movement of the celestial mechanism. How could one know whether it is so or not? The implication is that those who study the Dao and practice the work of forgetting the self must first observe this body as a shadow, like a snake’s scales or a cicada’s wings, and the attachment to self will naturally dissolve.)

In the past, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly, fluttering happily as a butterfly. He was so content that he forgot he was Zhou. Suddenly he awoke, and there he was, sprawled as Zhou. But was it Zhou who dreamed he was a butterfly, or a butterfly dreaming it was Zhou? Between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction. (This speaks of the difference between dream and waking, yet it is all Zhou. How could the butterfly be Zhou, or Zhou the butterfly? Here, there must be clarity—one must see through this to regard life and death as dream and waking, and all things as one, thus eliminating the debates over right and wrong.) This is called *"the transformation of things"* (the transformation of things means all things merge into one. As it is said, *"Great transformation is called sageliness"*—the ultimate in aligning things can only be achieved by the sage of great transformation. When the myriad things blend and transform into one, then all distinctions of self and other, right and wrong vanish, and the inconsistencies of judgments naturally align. The alignment of things concludes with the metaphor of a dream, shattering the great dream of all the world, past and present. From this, we see that Zhuangzi’s learning is not easily attained—it is not merely about the text.)

This concludes the ultimate transformation in the alignment of things, thus presenting the indistinction of dream and waking, with the transformation of things as the highest principle. The general intent of this discourse is that to align things, one must first break the attachment to self as the foremost task. Hence, it begins with *"I have lost my self."* Here, *"I"* refers to the true master, while *"self"* is the bodily form. Initially, it speaks of forgetting the self, not yet addressing the work; next, the work of forgetting the self requires observing that the bodily form is illusory, seeing through the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera one by one, scattering them all—within them, who is truly the self? Only then is the true lord revealed. The implication is that if one awakens to the true lord, then the bodily form can be transcended; with the bodily form transcended, the self is naturally forgotten...

**Chapter Three: The Preservation of Life**

My life has limits, but knowledge is without limit. To pursue the limitless with the limited is perilous! And to do so while already knowing this is perilous indeed! Follow the central path as your guiding principle—this can preserve the body, complete life, nourish one’s kin, and fulfill one’s years.

Butcher Ding carved an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, where his shoulder leaned, where his foot pressed, where his knee braced—*hua!*—the blade sang, *huo!*—each stroke struck true to rhythm, harmonizing with the dance of *Sanglin* and the cadence of *Jingshou*. Never was there haste or strain, only the effortless grace of a master.

Lord Wenhui exclaimed, “Ah! How marvelous! How has your skill reached such perfection?”

Butcher Ding laid down his knife and replied, “What your servant pursues is the Dao, which transcends mere technique. When I first began carving oxen, all I saw was the whole ox. After three years, I no longer saw the ox as a whole—for by then, I perceived its natural divisions: the head, horns, hooves, and flanks without; the five viscera, hundred bones, sinews, and joints within. Each part had its own principle, its own order, its own unforced pattern. Thus, I came to see that there was no ‘whole ox’ at all. Now, I encounter the ox with my spirit rather than my eyes. My senses stand still while my spirit moves, guided by the natural grain. My hand follows where it will, and the blade finds its way through the seams.”

chunks.translated_text:
Following the natural grain—guided by the inherent patterns of flesh and bone—he cleaved the great seams and guided the blade through the great cavities, all by yielding to what was already so. Never once did his edge touch the knots where sinew binds to bone, much less the great bones themselves. For when the knife moves by principle, even the smallest junctures yield without resistance, let alone the massive bones that might obstruct.

A skilled butcher wears out a knife each year, for he cuts by force. An ordinary butcher wears out a knife each month, for he hacks and chops. Yet my blade has served nineteen years, carving thousands of oxen, and its edge remains as keen as if newly whetted. For the joints have spaces, and the blade has no thickness. When what has no thickness enters where there is space, how ample the room for the blade to move! Thus, after nineteen years, my knife is still as if freshly honed.

Yet whenever I come to a tangled knot of sinew and bone, I see the difficulty. I grow wary, my gaze fixes, my movements slow. The blade moves with the slightest motion, and suddenly—*hua!*—the knot falls apart like clods of earth crumbling to the ground. Then I stand with knife in hand, look around in satisfaction, linger a moment to savor the achievement, wipe the blade clean, and put it away.”

Duke Wenhui exclaimed, “Excellent! From Butcher Ding’s words, I have learned how to nurture life.”

chunks.translated_text:
This "Nurturing the Life-Principle" chapter establishes its meaning through the single episode of Butcher Ding’s dissection of an ox, which fully embodies the subtleties of nurturing life—nothing more than a grand metaphor. If one aligns each element precisely, its marvel becomes evident.

Butcher Ding represents the sage; the ox, the affairs of the world. From the vastness of the realm and the state to the minutiae of daily conduct, all are matters before one’s eyes. The skill of dissecting the ox is the art and wisdom of governing the realm, the state, and engaging with the world. The knife symbolizes one’s original nature, the master of life—acting in accord with one’s nature is like using the knife to dissect the ox.

It speaks of the sage who studies the Dao, awakening subtly to the truth of nature, then extending its threads to govern the realm and state, just as Butcher Ding first learned the Dao before applying it to his craft. Before awakening, one sees only conflict with the world, difficult to navigate—like Butcher Ding, who at first saw nothing but the whole ox. Yet as one deepens in the Dao and the wisdom of nature grows clearer, the affairs of the world are seen through, each possessing its own inherent, natural principle. Thus, no single matter appears before one as an obstacle, and "the eye no longer sees the whole ox."

Having seen through worldly affairs, one acts solely in accord with Heaven’s principle, finding no difficulty whatsoever—this is what is meant by "never encountering the knots of sinew and bone." By proceeding in harmony with principle, one avoids the exhausting pursuit of gain that harms the truth of one’s nature. Thus, like the knife’s edge after nineteen years, it remains as if newly whetted, entirely free from the slightest nick or flaw.

With the sage’s clarity and discerning wisdom applied to matters that accord with principle, even small tasks are met with vast capacity—like the blade gliding through ample space. If one encounters difficult, unprincipled matters, like tangled knots of sinew and bone, one need only proceed with caution, deliberating carefully, and they too will be easily resolved, their difficulty no longer apparent.

How could one so attuned to the world be wearied and worn, inviting harm to life and nature? Thus, the chapter concludes: "From Butcher Ding’s words, I have learned how to nurture life." The intent lies in the sage’s alignment with nature, acting without excess, thereby preserving one’s nature and sparing the body from harm. One must deeply grasp this meaning, transcending the words themselves.

Such metaphors are found only in Buddhist sutras; they are utterly absent from secular texts, making them all the more worthy of careful reflection, for they contain profound significance.

The following passage speaks of those who fail to nurture life:

Gongwen Xuan, upon seeing the Chamberlain Right (an official title, referring to a one-legged man), exclaimed in shock, “What manner of man is this? How did he lose his foot? Was it Heaven’s doing, or man’s?” He replied, “It was Heaven, not man. Heaven gave him life to stand alone (meaning the Chamberlain Right was born with desires that corrupted his Heaven-endowed nature, thus incurring the punishment of amputation—Heaven’s penalty, leaving him solitary). Man’s form is bestowed by Heaven. Knowing this, one sees that his loss of a foot was Heaven’s doing, not man’s.”

A marsh pheasant takes ten steps to peck, a hundred steps to drink, yet does not seek to be caged. Though its spirit may thrive, it finds no goodness in such confinement (the pheasant, though its sustenance is hard-won, willingly follows its nature and refuses to be kept in a pen. Though the pen’s provisions may nourish its spirit, it knows the suffering of constraint and finds no comfort in it, thus rejecting it. The Chamberlain Right, greedy and heedless of his form, was far inferior to the marsh pheasant. Thus, his amputation was truly Heaven’s punishment, though he remained unaware).

This passage speaks of those who fail to nurture life: they lose sight of their true nature, forget their form in pursuit of gain, and bring harm to life and spirit upon themselves, far less attuned than the marsh pheasant.

Next, it speaks of even sages who, if they cannot forget emotion, also lose their Heaven-endowed nature. Thus, it invokes Laozi to illustrate:

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi came to offer condolences. He wailed three times and departed (showing no deep grief). His disciples asked, “Was he not your friend?” “Indeed,” he replied. “Then is it proper to offer condolences in such a manner?” they asked. “Yes,” he said. “At first, I thought him a true person (meaning when I first befriended him, I believed him to be one who had attained the Dao), but now I see he was not (after his death, I realized he had not). When I entered to offer condolences, I saw elders weeping for him as if for their own children, and the young weeping as if for their mothers. Those who gathered to mourn must have shared unspoken bonds with him, their hearts unable to restrain themselves—thus their grief, though unsummoned, was so profound. This is fleeing from Heaven and doubling back on emotion, forgetting what one has received. The ancients called this ‘the punishment of fleeing from Heaven’ (punishment here means principle). Lao Dan, in his conduct, could not forget emotion while in the world, thus forming attachments to others, who in turn could not forget him.”

chunks.translated_text:
This is truly self-fleeing from Heavenly truth, forgetting one’s original endowment. The ancients called this ‘fleeing and losing Heavenly truth, injuring one’s nature’—such a one is no sage.

As for coming, Master, it was timely (to come into being is to follow the time); as for going, Master, it was in accord (to depart in death is the transformation of creation. Yet the Heavenly truth remains serene, never having known coming or going, life or death). Abiding by the time and dwelling in accord, sorrow and joy cannot enter (to live is to rest in one’s time; to die is to follow transformation—how then could death bring sorrow or life bring joy? For one who grasps the fundamental absence of life and death). The ancients called this ‘the Great Clod’s suspended release’ (the Great Clod is the lord of life. Nature is bound to form, like a man hung upside down. Now, transcending and following transformation, one releases nature from its suspension).

The point exhausts itself in being firewood, yet the fire is transmitted—one knows not its end (though form transforms, nature endures, like firewood consumed yet fire remaining. There is luminous mutuality, like firewood and fire passing on. Thus life is ceaselessly generated, transformation is without end. Like the transmission of firewood and fire, one knows not its exhaustion). This speaks of nature receiving its nourishment, so that Heavenly truth is preserved whole—then coming and going, life and death, are utterly without constraint. Thus the perfected one wanders in the world: though his form is the same as others’, his nature transcends things beyond, unaltered by the changes of life and death. This is truly due to having attained its proper nourishment. To nourish nature and restore truth is to be a true person.

Thus, in "Among the World of Men," it speaks of the true person wandering without intent, using the analogy of Cook Ding carving an ox to show the effect of nourishing life’s master. Though the chapters differ, their meaning is fundamentally connected.

"Among the World of Men"
This chapter expounds the Dao of the sage in the world. Yet "Nourishing Life’s Master" teaches not to harm life with worldly affairs, and the effort of nourishing life is gained through experiencing the world. If one can truly nourish oneself, then in engaging the world, one will naturally avoid the faults of flaunting talent, seeking fame, or forcing action without cause. In assisting a ruler or serving a command, one will avoid the suspicion of boasting of merit or exaggerating virtue. And this effort—through fasting of the mind, sitting in forgetfulness, and engaging the world with emptiness—can be free from harm.

It speaks at length of the difficulty of worldly affairs and human feelings: unless one is empty and awaits things, even a slight talent or desire for fame will inevitably lead to harm. Thus the chapter concludes that "lack of talent" is the ultimate principle. Only when one engages the world without harm does the mastery of nourishing life become evident, mutually illuminating the previous chapter.

Confucius was a sage who served the world, and Yan Hui was the foremost disciple of the sagely gate—thus they are invoked to lend weight, making the teaching credible.

Yan Hui sought an audience with Zhongni and asked to depart.
“Where are you going?” (Zhongni asked where he intended to go.)
“I am going to Wei.”
“What for?” (The implication being that even a humane person like Yan Hui should not force action without cause.)
“I have heard,” said Yan Hui, “that the Lord of Wei (Kuaikui) is in his prime (in the vigor of his years), and his conduct is solitary (he is harsh, self-willed, rejects remonstrance, and acts recklessly). He treats his state lightly and does not see his faults (he is heedless and dismissive of his state, unaware of his errors). He treats the deaths of his people lightly (he is indifferent to the people, so the dead are many), and the dead are measured by the state as if a marsh, like reeds (the dead are heaped like reeds in a marsh when the state is compared to a marsh)—the people have nowhere to turn (the people are distressed, with nowhere to appeal).

I once heard you say, Master: ‘Leave a well-ordered state (if a state is well-governed, do not seek office without merit); go to a disordered state (to quell disorder and support the endangered is to bring peace to the people). The gate of a physician has many sick’ (those who are good at saving their time are like a good physician whose gate has many sick people). I wish to apply what I have heard and consider its principles (Yan Hui had long heard the Master’s words, so he wished to apply what he had heard and consider its methods), hoping that the state might be cured (hoping to relieve the people of their suffering).”

Zhongni said, “Alas! You will likely go and suffer punishment! The Dao does not desire mixture (to study the Dao, one must focus the mind single-mindedly; one cannot allow the mind to be disordered). Mixture leads to multiplicity, multiplicity to disturbance, disturbance to sorrow, and sorrow cannot be saved (if the mind is cluttered, one disturbs oneself with many affairs; disturbance leads to sorrow, and sorrow cannot be remedied).

The utmost person of old first established it in himself before establishing it in others (the utmost person of old, in engaging the world, first established the Dao and virtue in himself, then applied what he had established to others. These two lines are the great principle of engaging the world—none but the Master could attain this). If what is established in oneself is not settled, how can one have leisure to reach the conduct of violent men? Moreover, do you know where virtue is scattered and whence knowledge emerges? Virtue is scattered by fame, and knowledge emerges from contention (virtue cannot be preserved because of fame’s scattering; when fame scatters, substance is diminished. Knowledge that is revealed externally provokes the beginning of contention).”

Knowledge is the tool of contention (once talent or knowledge is revealed, everyone envies it, leading to strife and unrest). This passage speaks of the greatest matters in navigating the world, with admonishing a ruler as foremost. If the sovereign has long distrusted you yet you abruptly press loyal counsel upon them, not only will they refuse to heed it, but you may bring about your own execution. Who but the great sage Confucius, profoundly versed in worldly affairs and wise in preserving himself, could grasp this? Even Yan Hui had not yet attained such understanding. This is the foremost concern in human affairs, hence it is addressed first.

“Moreover, in ancient times, Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan—both had cultivated their virtue, humbling themselves to soothe the people and opposing their superiors. (Guan Longfeng and Bigan established their reputations through loyalty, yet were ultimately killed. As ministers, they bent their bodies to comfort the ruler’s people. *Yufu* means to bow and console the people, displaying a demeanor of compassion. When the ruler failed to cherish the people, the ministers instead took it upon themselves to do so, seeking renown by contradicting the sovereign’s will. This provoked their wrath and brought about their deaths—was this not a path to death through the pursuit of fame?) Thus, their rulers used their cultivation to cast them out. They were seekers of fame. (These two sought fame through self-cultivation, opposing their rulers, so their rulers used their very cultivation to harm them—this was the fault of their pursuit of fame.)

In former times, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xu’ao, and Yu attacked Youhu. Their states were left desolate, their rulers turned into vengeful ghosts, and their own bodies suffered execution. Their campaigns did not cease, their pursuit of substance knew no end. (These two sages believed themselves to be acting with benevolence, eliminating tyranny and saving the people. Their quest for the substance of benevolence was unending, hence their ceaseless warfare. This, too, was the pursuit of fame, only multiplying the slaughter.) They were all seekers of fame and substance. (They sought the reputation of benevolence while waging war—achieving fame but losing its substance.) Have you alone not heard of this?

Fame and substance are things even sages cannot fully master. How much less can you? (Even the two sages could not fully attain or preserve both fame and substance—how could you?)”

This is to say that if Yan Hui recklessly acts without cause, seeking the substance of fame, he will surely fail to preserve himself, demonstrating the inevitability of punishment. Moreover, even sages cannot fully master fame and substance—how much less can ordinary people?

The above passage teaches Yan Hui that he must not go. Below, Confucius further asks about the way to proceed if he must.

“Nevertheless, if you must have a method, tell it to me.” (Confucius said: Though I have explained why you must not go, if the situation compels you, what means will you use? Tell me, and let us see.)

This passage speaks of those stubborn and defiant men who reject counsel—even if one serves them with utmost loyalty and reverence, it only serves to inflate their arrogance, contributing nothing to their virtue, and ultimately proves futile.

"Then let me be inwardly upright yet outwardly yielding, achieving success by emulating the ancients." (Upon hearing the Master’s words, Yan Hui, realizing that sincerity and single-minded devotion could not prevail, reconsidered and proposed: "If I maintain inner uprightness, adopt an outward demeanor of deference, and align myself with the ancients, employing these three methods, surely my endeavor will succeed.")

"Inward uprightness means aligning oneself with Heaven." (Yan Hui explained the meaning of these three methods: "To be inwardly upright and align with Heaven is to recognize that human nature is inherently upright, for this nature is endowed by Heaven. Since both he and I share this nature, I say: 'To align with Heaven is to know that both the Son of Heaven and I are children of Heaven. Why should I alone seek that others deem my words good or bad? If I act thus, people will call me a childlike innocent—this is what it means to align with Heaven.'") (For since our nature is fundamentally the same, the ruler and I are both children of Heaven. I need only speak from my true nature, without concern for whether he deems my words good or bad. If I fully express this sincere and unfeigned heart, he will regard me as a child without guile—what harm could come of this?)

"Outward yielding means aligning oneself with others. Bowing, kneeling, and curving one’s body are the rites of a minister. If all others observe these rites, how dare I not do the same? To act as others do is to avoid their reproach—this is what it means to align with others." (Outward yielding means fully observing the rites of a minister without lapsing in propriety—what fault could there be in this?)

"To achieve success by emulating the ancients means aligning oneself with antiquity. Though my words may instruct, their substance is reproof, for such words existed in antiquity, not in me. If I act thus, though my words may be direct, they will not be deemed offensive—this is what it means to align with antiquity." (To achieve success means to cite established precedents; to emulate the ancients means to measure oneself against them. Thus, though my words may reprove and clarify right and wrong, they are grounded in truth, being the words of the ancients, not my own empty discourse. In this way, though my words may be direct, since they do not originate from me, they will not be taken as an affront.)

"Would this approach then be acceptable?" (With these three methods, might success be within reach?)

Confucius said, "Alas! How could it be? Your methods are too numerous and lack stability." (He lamented its impossibility: "Your principles are too many and lack steadiness.") (Here, *zhengfa* means "principles" or "standards," while *die* means "stable" or "secure." To employ these three methods is to rely on too many standards, and thus they remain unsteady.) "Though you may hold firm, you will still be without fault."

This passage speaks of the three methods, which derive from Confucius’ teaching that the noble person has three reverences: to walk with Heaven is to revere Heaven; to walk with others is to revere the great person; to walk with the ancients is to revere the words of the sages. Yet the discussion here is seamless, leaving no trace—these three matters do not reach the boundless transformation of the sage, but remain within the common ways of the world. The meaning lies beyond the words.

Emptiness is the fasting of the heart.” (He teaches Yanzi that the fasting of the heart consists in dwelling in emptiness.)

Yanzi’s many methods had not yet departed from intention; all words proceeding from intention fail to forget contrivance. As long as contrivance is not forgotten, the self is not transformed. Thus, he is taught the fasting of the heart, taking emptiness as its ultimate state. In emptiness, self and other are both forgotten, the self is transformed, and things transform of themselves.

Yan Hui said, “Before I received this teaching, I indeed took myself to be Yan Hui. (Before instruction, I still clung to the notion of a self.) Now that I have received it, I no longer have a self—may this be called emptiness?” (Upon hearing the teaching of the fasting of the heart, he suddenly forgot himself—can this forgetting of self be called emptiness? Yan Hui’s sudden awakening upon a single word was thus.)

The Master said, “It is complete! (The principle of the fasting of the heart is fully realized here.) I will now tell you: (You are now ready to receive teaching.) If you can enter and wander within the world’s snares (the snares being the fences of the worldly net) without being moved by reputation (if you can move through the world, emptying yourself and forgetting all concerns, without using cunning to impress others and seek fame), then speak when there is resonance, and cease when there is none. (Do not cling to a fixed intention, but observe the other’s spirit and qi. If there is resonance, speak; if not, desist—do not force it.) Have no gate, no drastic remedy. (A gate means establishing a fixed doctrine. A drastic remedy is like a medicine that must cure—both are harmful and should not be used.) Dwell in unity and lodge in the unavoidable—then you will be near it. (Dwell in a single mind, free of duality. Respond to what is said, lodging your intent in the unavoidable, never acting with deliberate effort. Only then will you be near.)”

chunks.original_text: 绝迹易，无行地难（言逃人绝世，尚易独有； 涉世无心，不着形迹为难。 即老子“善行无辙迹”）。 为人使易以伪，为天使难以伪（圣人应世，乃天之使也。 若是为人之使，容可以伪。 圣人乘真心而御物，又安可以伪乎）。 闻以有翼飞者也，未闻以无翼飞者也（此有心、无心之喻也。 言世人有心为事，而成者有之； 若无心应物，而使人感化，若无翼而飞者，此未之闻也）﹔闻以有知知者矣，未闻以无知知者也（言世人皆以有知而知之。 圣人以无知而知者，盖言忘形绝智，以无心而应物者。 此其难者，未之闻也）。 瞻彼阕者，虚室生白（此心虚之喻也。 谓室中空虚，但有缺处，则容光必照，而虚室中即生白矣。 以喻心虚，则天光自发也），吉祥止止（言有心而动，则祸福随之，所谓吉凶、悔吝，生乎动者也。 今若心虚无物，则一念不生，虚明自照，悔吝全消，惟吉祥止止。 而言此虚心，乃吉祥所止之处也）。 夫且不止，是之谓坐驰（言人心皆本虚明，第人不安心止此，私欲萌发，则身坐于此而心驰于彼，是之谓坐驰）。 夫殉耳目内通而外于心知，鬼神将来舍，而况人乎（殉，作殉，犹丧失也。 言丧耳目之见闻，返见返闻，故云内通。 若内通融于心体，真光发露，则不用其妄心、妄知，如此则虚明寂照，与鬼神合其德，故鬼神将来舍矣，而况于人而不感化乎！ 此无翼而飞者也。 此教回之极处也）！ 是万物之化也（谓丧耳目，则形自忘； 外心知，则智自泯。 则物我两忘，我忘物化，则万物尽化为道矣），禹舜之纽（枢纽）也，伏羲、几蘧（古圣君也）之所行终，而况散焉者乎（言物我兼忘，万物尽化，此混归大道之原。 即禹之神圣，亦执为枢纽； 而伏羲、几蘧之大圣御世，终身所行； 而况散民乎？ 颜回能以此用世，又何强行之有哉）！ ” 此言涉世，先于事君。 此言辅君之难也。 苟非物我两忘、虚心御物、不得已而应之，决不能感君而离患。 若固执我见，持必然之志而强谏之，不但无补于君，且致杀身之祸。 此龙逢、比干之死，皆是之过也。 下言使命之难。 叶公子高（叶公名梁，字子高，楚大夫也）将使于齐，问于仲尼曰：“王使诸梁也甚重（意将有兵革之事）。 齐之待使者，盖将甚敬而不急（言齐君待使者，貌虽恭而心甚慢，不能应使者之急事）。 匹夫犹未可动也，而况诸侯乎（言楚之事甚急，而齐若慢之，则不敢轻意催促。 且匹夫尚不可轻动，况诸侯乎）！ 吾甚栗之（恐误国事而取罪，故甚恐惧也）。 子常语诸梁也曰：‘凡事若小若大，寡不道以欢成（尝忆夫子教我，谓事无大小，必以欢成。 倘齐之不欢，则事难济矣。 此所以恐也）。 事若不成，则必有人道之患（言事若不成，君能无罪我乎？ 是必有人道之患也）﹔事若成，则必有阴阳之患（言齐倘不急，必多方劳虑，委曲求成，则焦劳之病，乃阴阳之内患也）。 若成若不成，而后无患者，唯有德者能之（有德者，谓全德之圣人也。 意谓事之成与不成，俱无患者，惟圣人虚心应世，不以物为事者能之也）。 ’吾食也执粗而不臧（善也，谓不甘美之厚味也），爨无欲清之人（言我之饮食淡薄，无多烹庖，故执爨之人，无有怕热而求清凉者）。

"To vanish without a trace is easy; to walk the earth without leaving a mark is difficult. (To escape others and withdraw from the world is still relatively easy when one remains alone; to engage with the world without intent, leaving no trace of form or action, is far harder—just as Laozi said, 'The skilled traveler leaves no tracks.') To be employed by men is easy to feign; to be employed by Heaven is difficult to feign. (When the sage responds to the world, it is as Heaven’s emissary. If one were merely an emissary of men, pretense might suffice. But the sage rides the true heart in governing things—how could pretense ever serve?)

We have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings. (This is a metaphor for acting with intent versus without. People may succeed in affairs when they act with intent, but to respond to things without intent, moving others as if flying without wings—this is unheard of.) We have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge. (People all know through having knowledge. The sage knows without knowledge, for he forgets form and transcends intellect, responding to things with a heart devoid of intent. This is the difficulty—something unheard of.)

Behold that empty space: in a vacant room, brightness arises. (This is a metaphor for the emptiness of the heart. When a room is empty, even a small opening allows light to enter, and brightness fills the vacant space. Likewise, when the heart is empty, the light of Heaven naturally shines forth.) Auspiciousness comes to rest where it rests. (When one acts with intent, fortune and misfortune follow—so-called good and ill fortune, regret and shame, all arise from action. But if the heart is empty of things, not a single thought arises, and clarity shines of itself. Regret and shame vanish entirely, and only auspiciousness comes to rest. This empty heart is where auspiciousness abides.)

Yet if one does not rest here, this is called 'sitting while galloping.' (The human heart is originally empty and bright, but if one does not settle the mind here, private desires arise, and though the body sits still, the heart races elsewhere—this is 'sitting while galloping.') If one loses the pursuit of the ears and eyes, turning inward to unify them, and goes beyond the heart’s knowledge, then spirits and gods will come to dwell—how much more so men! (To lose the pursuit of the ears and eyes means to return to true seeing and hearing, hence 'turning inward to unify.' If this inward unity merges with the heart’s essence, the true light shines forth, and one no longer relies on deluded thoughts or false knowledge. Then, in emptiness and clarity, stillness and illumination, one’s virtue aligns with spirits and gods, and they will come to dwell—how much more will men be moved! This is flying without wings. This is the utmost teaching of return.)

This is the transformation of the ten thousand things. (To lose the ears and eyes is to forget form; to go beyond the heart’s knowledge is to extinguish intellect. When self and things are both forgotten, and the self forgets while things transform, then the ten thousand things all become the Dao.) It is the pivot of Yu and Shun, the lifelong practice of Fuxi and Jiqu, and how much more so for those of scattered minds! (When self and things are both forgotten and the ten thousand things all transform, this is returning to the origin of the great Dao. Even the divine sage Yu held it as his pivot, and the great sages Fuxi and Jiqu governed the world by it throughout their lives—how much more should ordinary people do so! Yan Hui could apply this in the world—what forced action would there be?)

This speaks of engaging with the world, first in serving one’s lord. This speaks of the difficulty of assisting a lord. If one does not forget both self and things, govern with an empty heart, and respond only to what cannot be avoided, one will never move the lord or avoid disaster. If one stubbornly clings to one’s own views, holds fast to unyielding intentions, and forces remonstrance, not only will it fail to benefit the lord, but it will bring about the calamity of death. This was the error that led to the deaths of Longfeng and Bigan.

Below, the difficulty of missions is discussed. When Viscount Zigao of She (Zigao was the courtesy name of Liang, a grandee of Chu) was about to be sent on a mission to Qi, he asked Confucius: 'The king’s charge to me is most weighty (implying matters of war and conflict). The way Qi treats envoys is outwardly respectful but inwardly slow to act (though Qi’s lord appears reverent toward envoys, his heart is negligent and cannot address urgent matters). Even a common man cannot be lightly moved—how much less a feudal lord! (The affairs of Chu are urgent, yet if Qi is slow, one dare not press them. Even a common man cannot be lightly moved—how much less a feudal lord!) I am deeply fearful of this. (Fearing that I will fail in the state’s affairs and incur punishment, I am greatly afraid.)

You once told me: 'In all matters, great or small, few succeed without joyful accord. (I recall your teaching that in all affairs, whether great or small, success requires joyful accord. If Qi is not joyful, the matter will be difficult to accomplish—this is why I fear.) If the matter does not succeed, there will surely be human-caused calamity. (If the matter fails, will the lord not punish me? There will surely be human-caused calamity.) If it succeeds, there will surely be calamity from the imbalance of yin and yang. (If Qi is slow, one must labor in many ways, seeking success through compromise—then the strain of anxiety will bring illness, a calamity of yin and yang.) Only one with virtue can succeed or fail without calamity. (One with virtue refers to a sage of complete virtue. Only the sage, who responds to the world with an empty heart and does not treat things as affairs, can succeed or fail without calamity.')

My food is coarse and not refined (not indulging in rich flavors), and my kitchen has no one seeking coolness. (My food is simple and plain, with little cooking, so those tending the stove do not seek coolness to escape the heat.)"

chunks.original_text: 今吾朝受命而夕饮冰，我其内热欤（言素无厚味，故无内热之症。 今朝受命而夕饮冰，则火症内发，乃忧愁焦思以动其火耳，其内热之病欤）！ 吾未至乎事之情（实也），而既有阴阳之患矣（言未就事，早有阴阳失错、内热之病矣）！ 事若不成，必有人道之患（事若不成，国君能无罪我乎？ 此人道之患，所不免者），是两也。 为人臣者不足以任之（言此两患在身，事不由己，故为人臣者所不能任之也），子其有以语我来（愿夫子有以教我也）！ ” 此言人臣以使命为难也。 以为人臣者，但以一己功名为心，故事必求可功，必求成，以此横虑交错于胸中，劳神焦思之若此。 乃举世人臣使命之难，绝不知有所处之道，故不免其患耳。 故夫子教以处之之方，意有一定之命、一定之理，安顺处之，自无患耳。 若持必可之心，固所不免也。 下夫子教其莫若致命，此其难者，将此起语为结。 仲尼曰：“天下有大戒二（大戒者，谓世之大经、大法也，乃君亲之命不可易者）：其一，命也，其一，义也。 子之爱亲，命也，不可解于心﹔臣之事君，义也，无适而非君也（庄子诽仁义，独于人之事君，以义为主，又以死忠为不善。 今言人臣之事君，无往而非君，乃忠之盛也。 此老何曾越世故耶），无所逃于天地之间。 是之谓大戒（言世之君亲之命无所逃，此乃世之大经、大法之不易者）。 是以夫事其亲者，不择地而安之，孝之至也（言子之事亲，无往而非亲命，则不敢择地而安之，此乃孝之至也）﹔夫事其君者，不择事而安之，忠之盛也（言事君者，唯命是听，不敢以难易二其心，乃忠之盛也。 故古人耻贰心以事主者）； 自事其心者，哀乐不易施乎前（言孝则当竭其力，忠则尽乎命，以尽心尽命为主，不以难易推移之志。 此事心之大者，不以哀乐入于心也），知其不可奈何而安之若命，德之至也（言人臣之分，知其事之虽无可奈何，亦不敢贰心相视，但安之若命。 安命则忘其难易，此乃德之至也）。 为人臣子者，固有所不得已。 行事之情而忘其身（言人之臣子，固有不得已之事，但当尽命以忘其身以从事），何暇至于悦生而恶死（言臣子尽命而已，岂敢以生死为去就哉）！ 夫子其行可矣（教叶公，但当如此而行，可矣）！ ” 庄子全书，皆以忠孝为要名誉、丧失天真之不可尚者，独人间世一篇，则极尽其忠孝之实，一字不可易者，谁言其人不达世故，而恣肆其志耶？ 且借重孔子之言者，曷尝侮圣人哉？ 盖学，有方内、方外之分。
chunks.translated_text:
This morning I received my charge, and by evening I am drinking ice—does this mean I suffer from internal heat? (I have long eaten plain food, so I should have no internal heat. Yet now, upon receiving my charge in the morning, I drink ice by evening, for the fire syndrome has flared within—this comes from anxiety, sorrow, and overthinking stirring the fire. Is this not the illness of internal heat?) I have not yet grasped the true nature of the matter (its reality), yet already I suffer from the affliction of yin and yang imbalance (I have not even begun the task, yet already I am stricken with the disorder of yin and yang and the illness of internal heat). If the matter fails, there will surely be human-caused calamity (if the matter fails, will the lord not punish me? This is the human-caused calamity one cannot escape). Thus I face two perils. As a minister, I am not equal to this burden (these two perils weigh upon me, and the matter lies beyond my control—thus a minister cannot bear it). Pray, sir, instruct me in how to proceed (I wish you would teach me how to act)."

This speaks of the difficulty of a minister’s mission. For a minister, if he concerns himself only with his own reputation and success, he will inevitably seek achievement and completion, his mind entangled with endless calculations, his spirit worn by anxiety and overthinking. Yet all ministers in the world face the difficulty of such missions, utterly unaware of how to conduct themselves, and thus cannot escape calamity. Therefore, the Master teaches the way to conduct oneself: there is a fixed mandate and a fixed principle; if one accepts and follows them with equanimity, one will naturally avoid calamity. But if one clings to the certainty of success, one cannot escape it.

Confucius said: "There are two great precepts in the world (great precepts refer to the world’s great principles and laws, the unalterable commands of ruler and parent): the first is mandate, the second is duty. A child’s love for a parent is mandate—it cannot be untied from the heart. A minister’s service to his lord is duty—there is nowhere he may go that is not his lord’s (Zhuangzi criticizes benevolence and duty, yet when it comes to a minister’s service to his lord, he takes duty as primary, even deeming death in loyalty unworthy. Here, he says that in a minister’s service to his lord, there is nowhere he may go that is not his lord’s—this is the height of loyalty. How could Laozi have transcended worldly concerns?). There is no escape from them in heaven and earth. These are called the great precepts (the commands of ruler and parent cannot be escaped—these are the world’s great, unchanging principles and laws).

Thus, one who serves a parent does not choose a place to find peace—this is the height of filial piety (a child serving a parent has nowhere to go that is not the parent’s command; thus he does not dare choose a place to find peace—this is the height of filial piety). One who serves a lord does not choose the matter to find peace—this is the height of loyalty (one who serves a lord obeys commands without hesitation, never allowing difficulty or ease to divide his heart—this is the height of loyalty. Thus the ancients felt shame at serving their lords with a divided heart). One who serves his own heart does not allow sorrow or joy to alter what lies before him (filial piety demands exhausting one’s strength; loyalty demands fulfilling one’s mandate. The essence is to devote heart and mandate fully, never allowing difficulty or ease to sway one’s resolve. This is the greatest service to the heart—never allowing sorrow or joy to enter it). Knowing that something is beyond one’s control yet accepting it as mandate—this is the height of virtue (a minister’s duty is to know that a matter may be beyond remedy yet never allow a divided heart to regard it. One must accept it as mandate. Accepting mandate means forgetting difficulty and ease—this is the height of virtue).

As a minister or child, one is bound by what one cannot avoid. One acts according to the true nature of the matter, forgetting oneself (a minister or child is bound by unavoidable duties; one must fulfill one’s mandate, forgetting oneself in the task). How could one have leisure to delight in life and fear death (a minister or child fulfills their mandate—how dare they consider life and death in their choices)? You may proceed thus (teaching Lord She, one should act in this way—it is sufficient)."

Throughout the *Zhuangzi*, loyalty and filial piety are deemed mere reputation, harmful to natural integrity and unworthy of esteem. Yet in the "Human World" chapter alone, he exhausts their true essence, not a word of which can be altered. Who would say he was ignorant of worldly affairs, giving free rein to his own will? And in invoking Confucius’ words, did he ever disrespect the sage? For in learning, there is a distinction between the inner and outer ways.

chunks.translated_text:
"In the outer way, one must esteem unboundedness as lofty, yet it is essential to return to the great Dao. As for the inner way, in matters of ruler-minister and father-child relationships, not a single concession can be made—this is because the great norms and great laws of the world must not be violated. This is what is meant by the Dao of the worldly and the transcendent, which encompasses all without exception and exhausts all principles. How could one view them with a single perspective?

'Let me reiterate what I have heard (having broadly spoken of the righteousness of ruler-minister and father-child relationships, I shall now further discuss the principles of diplomatic missions): In dealings with neighboring states, one must align with trustworthiness (靡 means compliance; 信 means verification. In interactions with neighboring states, verification is indispensable, leaving no room for mere rhetoric). In dealings with distant states, one must be faithful in speech (when engaging with distant states, one must employ faithful rhetoric to harmonize the joy of both nations). Words must be conveyed through messengers (meaning words must be transmitted orally by envoys). Conveying words that bring double joy or double anger is the most difficult task under heaven (the stakes of such words determine safety or peril, and fortune or misfortune follows). When both parties are pleased, there will be an excess of flattery; when both are angered, there will be an excess of slander (the flaw lies in excess). All excess is delusion (excessive praise or slander arises from overreliance on cunning, thus losing its original truth—hence, it is delusion). Delusion cannot be trusted (since the words lack sincerity, the listener remains unmoved and disbelieving). If not trusted, the messenger incurs misfortune (once disbelief arises, the fault lies with the messenger, who will suffer the consequences). Thus, the standard teaching says: "Transmit the constant sentiments, do not transmit excess words (constant sentiments are truthful and unadulterated). Then one may nearly preserve wholeness."'

This passage speaks of the difficulty of diplomatic missions, where the interests of both parties rest upon the envoy’s shoulders. If words exceed reality, they breed doubt and disbelief in the listener, becoming the root of disaster, and the messenger will inevitably bear the calamity. Thus, truthfulness and absence of delusion are prized, for they may nearly ensure preservation.

The following text elaborates: though one may provisionally preserve the matter at hand, in the end, great harm will surely follow. Words are not easily spoken—one must be cautious from the very beginning.

'Moreover, those who contend with skill and strength begin with harmony but often end in conflict; when taken to extremes, they resort to excessive cunning (this speaks of the principle of caution at the outset and the end). Consider those who initially engage in playful contests of skill and strength: at first, both parties are in good spirits, but as the contest intensifies, a desire to prevail arises, and each employs their own cunning. Once cunning emerges, injury is inevitable; once injury occurs, the matter becomes earnest and irresolvable, culminating in anger. Here, *yang* signifies joy, and *yin* signifies anger.'"
